paper_metadata.title: Acquisitions, Node Collapse, and Network Revolution
paper_metadata.research_context: Interorganizational networks; mergers and acquisitions conceptualized as node collapses; multi-period, multi-agent simulations comparing node collapses vs. tie additions to study network evolution, firm performance, and structural properties.

constructs.definition: From a networks lens, an acquisition consists of the collapse of two nodes by which the acquirer gains ownership of the target’s ties. Such node collapse can radically restructure the network by modifying multiple ties in a single transaction, producing revolutionary change compared with incremental tie additions/deletions. It creates externalities for other actors and provides the acquirer with control over both internal resources (owned by the target) and external resources (accessed via inherited network ties).
constructs.context_snippet: From a networks lens, an acquisition consists of the collapse of two nodes by which the acquirer gains ownership of the target’s ties... constituting a revolutionary change... Node collapses also have an impact on the existence and distribution of ties for nodes not involved directly in the acquisition.

constructs.definition: The profit for actor i in period t is a function of resources accessed and a cost of size: π_it = Σ_j (r_ijt × (spl_ijt + 1)^d)^1.5 − c × (size_it)^2. The first term captures the positive effect of the amount of resources (r_ijt) weighted by the distance they traveled ((spl_ijt + 1)^d), while the second term penalizes firm size via parameter c.
constructs.context_snippet: The profit for actor i in period t is given by πit = ∑j (rijt × (splijt + 1)^d)^1.5 − c(sizeit)^2. The first term captures the positive effect of resources... the second term captures the negative effect of firm size.

constructs.definition: An ego-network metric equal to the number of ties possessed by an actor in a given period.
constructs.context_snippet: We capture the degree centrality of each actor as the number of ties it possesses in each period.

constructs.definition: An ego-network measure inversely related to structural holes, capturing network closure: c_i = Σ_j (p_ij + Σ_q p_iq p_qj)^2, where p_ij is the proportion of i’s total network ties represented by j. Low values indicate many structural holes; high values indicate high closure/density.
constructs.context_snippet: We follow prior work by measuring structural holes based on network constraint (Burt 1992): ci = ∑j (pij + ∑q piq pqj)^2... Recall that low values of constraint represent networks rich in structural holes while high values capture networks with high closure or density.

constructs.definition: Gaps between otherwise disconnected network clusters that an actor can bridge to access novel resources; operationalized inversely by the constraint measure (lower constraint indicates more structural holes).
constructs.context_snippet: Constraint is (inversely) associated with access to structural holes, whereby firms gain novel resources from bridging disconnected clusters.

constructs.definition: A global network measure of community structure using Girvan and Newman’s approach: Q = 1/e · Σ_k (e_kk − {e_kk}), where e is total ties, e_kk ties within community k, and {e_kk} expected within-community ties. Higher Q indicates more distinct densely connected subgroups weakly connected to others.
constructs.context_snippet: We capture community structure using Girvan and Newman’s (2002) approach to finding the modularity of the network, as Q = 1/e · ∑k (ekk − {ekk}).

constructs.definition: Resources owned by a firm, including those of acquired targets after node collapses; these are fully accessible (probability 1) to the owning firm and can generate internal synergies through combination.
constructs.context_snippet: The former [internal] may give rise to “internal synergies,” as discussed by previous M&A research... the ability of the acquirer to take ownership and thus control of the target’s resources.

constructs.definition: Resources accessed through network ties from other firms; access probability decreases with network distance and is governed by the transmission parameter. Node collapses can enhance access by inheriting target ties.
constructs.context_snippet: External ones gained from inheriting the network ties of the target... value could stem from... “network synergies” — the improvement in the acquirer’s network position resulting from the structural change in the network because of a node collapse.

constructs.definition: Value created from combining owned resources of acquirer and target such that the combination produces greater value than separate entities (e.g., efficiency, capacity), typically emphasized in M&A research.
constructs.context_snippet: The literature uses the notion of synergy — a combination of assets that produces greater value together than separate — to explain how much value can be created from the transaction... research has emphasized those stemming from resources owned by firms, which we label “internal synergies.”

constructs.definition: The improvement in the acquirer’s network position and access to external resources resulting from structural change due to a node collapse, including inherited ties and altered brokerage.
constructs.context_snippet: We raise the possibility of network synergies stemming from the structural recombination of the ties of the merging entities, and we demonstrate that the direction of network evolution depends on which of the two types of synergies firms pursue through node collapses.

constructs.definition: A parameter tr ∈ [0,1] determining friction in the flow of resources through the network. The probability that firm i receives resources from firm j is tr^(spl_ijt), where spl_ijt is the shortest path length. tr=0 implies no transmission; tr=1 implies guaranteed transmission along any path.
constructs.context_snippet: A “transmission” parameter, tr ∈ [0,1], determines how much friction there is in the flow of resources through the network. The probability that a firm i obtains access to resources from firm j is then given by tr^splijt.

constructs.definition: A parameter d that weights resources by network distance in the performance function: (spl_ijt + 1)^d. Low d emphasizes amounts; high d emphasizes distant (novel) resources.
constructs.context_snippet: On the resource side... (splijt + 1)^d can be thought of as a distance-based weighting factor... low values (e.g., d=0) represent situations in which performance is driven solely by the amount... high values (e.g., d=1) represent cases in which resources that come from far across the network are more valuable.

constructs.definition: The geodesic distance between two firms in the network at time t, used both to compute transmission probability (tr^spl) and distance weighting ((spl + 1)^d).
constructs.context_snippet: The probability that a firm receives a resource through network transmission decreases the farther away it is... (i.e., it decreases in the shortest path length between the two firms).

constructs.term: cost of being a large firm
constructs.definition: A parameter c ≥ 0 that penalizes size in the performance function via −c × (size_it)^2, capturing diseconomies of size and limits to value from absorbing many nodes.
constructs.context_snippet: On the cost side, size_it captures the number of nodes “owned” by firm i... and c is a parameter that determines how much firms are penalized for being large.

constructs.definition: The number of nodes possessed (owned) by a firm, which increases when it acquires targets (internalizes their nodes).
constructs.context_snippet: Initially, all firms have a “size” of one node. As they acquire other firms, acquirers internalize the nodes of targets and thus grow in size, defined as the number of nodes possessed by the firm.

constructs.definition: A global indicator of network shrinkage over time as node collapses occur; convergence is reached when no more node collapses occur.
constructs.context_snippet: We consider the simulation to have reached convergence when no more node collapses occur... Figure 2(a) depicts the number of firms remaining in the network after each period for the default case.

constructs.definition: A dispersion measure of firm sizes in the network used to assess how egalitarian or concentrated the network becomes.
constructs.context_snippet: We are also interested in their distribution (e.g., standard deviation) across firms in the network. This allows us to get at issues of performance and competitive advantage.

constructs.definition: A network change mechanism where a firm forms a new tie with another firm; modeled in a comparison simulation to assess per-transaction impacts relative to node collapses.
constructs.context_snippet: Additionally, we build another simulation in which actors similarly pursue resources but can only add ties to one another... We compare some of the main findings to those produced by the tie addition simulation.

relationships.boundary_conditions: Effect pertains to the acquirer (focal firm) per transaction during periods when node collapses occur.
relationships.context_snippet: Node collapses always increase performance for the focal firm (i.e., the acquirer).
relationships.causal_notes: Result derived from agent-based simulation varying network via acquisitions.

relationships.boundary_conditions: Increase holds generally; slight decrease in very late stages when the network becomes extremely small.
relationships.context_snippet: Degree centrality generally increased for the acquiring firm with each node collapse... in late stages acquisitions slightly decrease degree centrality, a mechanical artifact of the extremely small network size.
relationships.causal_notes: Per-transaction average effect tracked over time.

relationships.boundary_conditions: Decrease holds generally; constraint increases in very late periods when the network is extremely small and densely linked.
relationships.context_snippet: Network constraint generally declined with each transaction, suggesting... increasing access to structural holes.

relationships.boundary_conditions: Observed over time as collapses occur; pertains to global network structure.
relationships.context_snippet: The modularity of the network decreases over time. This means... decreasing number of distinct clusters in the network.

relationships.boundary_conditions: World of increasing returns to scale; effect is that network shrinkage slows compared to purely internal incentives.
relationships.context_snippet: In a world of increasing returns to scale, network synergies provide a force that balances against rapid or complete network collapse.
relationships.causal_notes: Assessed by comparing dynamics with and without network transmission.

relationships.boundary_conditions: World of decreasing returns to scale; network synergies facilitate node collapses and network shrinkage.
relationships.context_snippet: In a world of decreasing returns to scale, network synergies can facilitate node collapses and lead to network shrinkage.

relationships.boundary_conditions: Effect pertains to actors not directly involved in the acquisition; measured as total effect on others per transaction.
relationships.context_snippet: Node collapses tend to have a positive effect on the performance of the rest of the network.
relationships.causal_notes: Externality arises via increased internal resources of the acquirer and reduced distances.

relationships.boundary_conditions: Effect pertains to other actors (neither acquirer nor target); becomes less negative in very late stages as fewer common ties exist.
relationships.context_snippet: The degree centrality of a third party can never increase after a node collapse... Degree will decrease only when the third party was tied to the two merging nodes.

relationships.boundary_conditions: Effect pertains to other actors; holds when the focal actor seeks to increase access to structural holes (decrease own constraint).
relationships.context_snippet: Node collapses tend to indirectly close the network ties of parties formerly affiliated with the acquirer and target, resulting in decreased structural holes—increases in constraint for others.

relationships.subject_term: cost of being a large firm
relationships.boundary_conditions: Effect observed across early, middle, and late periods; higher c leads to fewer node collapses.
relationships.context_snippet: The number of firms remaining in the network increases with cost (i.e., fewer node collapses happen as cost increases).
relationships.section_header: Internal vs. Network Synergies: Diseconomies of Size

relationships.subject_term: cost of being a large firm
relationships.boundary_conditions: As cost rises, the network becomes more egalitarian; under low cost, dispersion increases over time.
relationships.context_snippet: The standard deviation in the average firm size decreases with cost and, when cost is low, increases dramatically over time.
relationships.section_header: Internal vs. Network Synergies: Diseconomies of Size

relationships.subject_term: cost of being a large firm
relationships.boundary_conditions: Higher c moves ego networks toward more openness (more structural holes).
relationships.context_snippet: At the ego level, we observe a significant decline in constraint as cost rises.
relationships.section_header: Internal vs. Network Synergies: Diseconomies of Size

relationships.subject_term: cost of being a large firm
relationships.boundary_conditions: As c increases, prevents a monopolist from devolving the network into a single component.
relationships.context_snippet: At the global level, modularity increases as cost rises because cost prevents a “monopolist” from devolving the network into a single component.
relationships.section_header: Internal vs. Network Synergies: Diseconomies of Size

relationships.boundary_conditions: Up to moderate d, dispersion effect increases firms remaining; at very high d (≈>1.8) in late periods, a hurdle-rate effect slightly reduces firms remaining.
relationships.context_snippet: As d rises, the number of firms remaining tends to increase... however, for very high values of d... the size of the network tends to fall in late periods.
relationships.causal_notes: Nonlinear due to competing dispersion vs. hurdle-rate effects.

relationships.boundary_conditions: Constraint tends to decline with d; at very high d in late stages, constraint increases slightly due to additional deals.
relationships.context_snippet: Average constraint... tends to decline in d... but at very high d and in late stages, the hurdle rate takes effect and pushes the network toward higher constraint.

relationships.boundary_conditions: As d increases, modularity increases; at very high d in late periods, tendency slightly reverses.
relationships.context_snippet: As expected, the importance of distant network resources pushes the network toward higher modularity initially as d increases. But at very high d at late stages, this tendency is slightly reversed.

relationships.boundary_conditions: Low-cost regime (c=0): as transmission increases, fewer node collapses happen and more firms remain.
relationships.context_snippet: Under low cost, the number of firms remaining increases as transmission increases.

relationships.boundary_conditions: Low-cost regime (c=0); effect clearest in late periods.
relationships.context_snippet: Constraint tends to decrease as transmission increases when cost is low (mainly in late periods, as expected).

relationships.boundary_conditions: Low-cost regime (c=0); effect observed over periods.
relationships.context_snippet: Modularity increases over transmission when cost is low.

relationships.boundary_conditions: High-cost regime (c=1): number of node collapses initially increases with transmission and then declines (implying firms remaining first decrease then increase).
relationships.context_snippet: Under high cost... transmission has a nonlinear effect on the number of remaining firms, with the highest number of node collapses occurring at moderate transmission levels.
relationships.causal_notes: Nonlinear (inverted-U) described qualitatively; exact shape not labeled.

relationships.boundary_conditions: High-cost regime (c=1): constraint initially increases and then decreases as transmission rises.
relationships.context_snippet: When cost is high it [constraint] has a nonlinear relationship with transmission—with the highest values of constraint... at moderate transmission.

relationships.boundary_conditions: High-cost regime (c=1): modularity initially decreases and then increases as transmission rises.
relationships.context_snippet: We observe that modularity... exhibits the expected nonlinear relationship in which modularity is lowest at moderate transmission levels when cost is high.

relationships.boundary_conditions: Effect pertains to focal firm per tie addition; impact per transaction is significantly weaker than node collapses.
relationships.context_snippet: In the tie addition simulation, degree centrality increased... but the rate at which they did so was much smaller compared with the node collapse simulation.
relationships.causal_notes: Comparison simulation with tie additions only.

relationships.boundary_conditions: Effect pertains to focal firm per tie addition; impact per transaction is significantly weaker than node collapses.
relationships.context_snippet: In the tie addition simulation, constraint decreased on average, but the rate... was much smaller compared with the node collapse simulation.

relationships.boundary_conditions: Externality on other actors; additions produce a slightly positive externality by increasing others’ access to structural holes (i.e., lowering their constraint).
relationships.context_snippet: Additions produce a slightly positive constraint externality (by increasing others’ access to structural holes), whereas collapses produce a strong negative externality.

measurements.name: Profit function (Equation 1)
measurements.details: π_it = Σ_j (r_ijt × (spl_ijt + 1)^d)^1.5 − c × (size_it)^2. Resources term uses increasing returns exponent 1.5 by default; distance-weighting parameter d; size penalty parameter c.
measurements.scoring_procedure: Compute expected payoffs using probabilistic network transmission and distance-weighted resources, then subtract size cost.
measurements.context_adaptations: Default d=0 and c=0 for baseline; variants include d>0 and c>0 for scenario analyses.

measurements.name: Network transmission probability
measurements.details: Probability resources flow from j to i decreases with network distance; parameter tr ∈ [0,1] governs friction.
measurements.scoring_procedure: For each i,j, compute probability as tr raised to shortest path length from i to j.
measurements.context_adaptations: tr=0 implies no transmission; tr=1 implies guaranteed transmission along any path.

measurements.name: Geodesic distance
measurements.details: Network distance between two firms at time t used for transmission and distance weighting.
measurements.scoring_procedure: Compute shortest path in the undirected network between nodes i and j.

measurements.name: Degree count
measurements.details: Number of ties for each actor per period.
measurements.scoring_procedure: Count incident edges on each node.

measurements.name: Burt’s network constraint
measurements.details: Constraint c_i = Σ_j (p_ij + Σ_q p_iq p_qj)^2, where p terms are tie proportions.
measurements.scoring_procedure: Compute proportional tie weights then apply Burt’s formula.
measurements.context_adaptations: Lower values indicate more structural holes.

measurements.name: Girvan–Newman modularity (Louvain algorithm)
measurements.details: Q = 1/e · Σ_k (e_kk − {e_kk}); estimated using the Louvain algorithm for efficiency.
measurements.scoring_procedure: Detect communities via Louvain method and compute Q.
measurements.context_adaptations: Higher Q indicates stronger community structure.

measurements.name: Owned node count
measurements.details: Number of nodes possessed by a firm; increases via acquisitions.
measurements.scoring_procedure: Sum of nodes internalized by each firm.

measurements.name: Network size over time
measurements.details: Count of distinct firms (nodes) remaining at each period; indicator of network shrinkage.
measurements.scoring_procedure: Count nodes after applying acquisitions in each period.
measurements.context_adaptations: Convergence when no more node collapses occur.

measurements.name: Dispersion of firm sizes
measurements.details: Standard deviation of firm size distribution used to assess egalitarian vs. concentrated structure.
measurements.scoring_procedure: Compute standard deviation across firms’ sizes each period.

core_theories.name: structural holes theory
core_theories.grounding_phrase: Constraint is (inversely) associated with access to structural holes...
core_theories.evidence: Used to interpret decreases/increases in constraint as access to novel resources and to explain externalities.

core_theories.name: theory of the firm
core_theories.grounding_phrase: the cost of being a large firm... getting at diseconomies of size (Coase 1937)
core_theories.evidence: Cost parameter c embodies diseconomies of size limiting growth and shaping acquisition incentives.
